## 2. Project overview üåæüìä

### 2.1 Project idea (short description)
In few sentences, describe: <br/>

  The agricultural context (what system/crop/problem?) <br/>
- The purpose of this data analysis project is to examine phosphorous (P) rates and sources in RCBD plots across two locations.  
- Soil data were collected at the plot level and can be linked to fertilizer rates to determine the amount of P in each plot.  
- The goal is to re-evaluate current P rates for corn and soybean in southern Ontario.  

  The data science task (what will you do with the data?) <br/>
- Explore the data to determine if there is any correlation or relationship between P levels and relative yield values.   
- Investigate the variables to uncover any other correlations or relationships within the data.  

### 2.2 Motivation / why it matters üåé

In just a few bullets, explain why this project is interesting or useful (scientifically, agronomically, or practically). <br/>

-  Agronomically, Ontario P rate reccommendations need to be updated.
-  Interestingly, this project uses soil samples at the plot level rather than the block level to uncover soil nutrient spatial variability.

## 3. Objectives & research questions ‚ùì

Write **main objectives** (2-3 max.). Keep them specific and realistic for the semester.

### 3.1 Objectives
1. Find the correlation between phosphorous levels and relative yield.
2. Uncover the insufficient rate of phosphorus fertilizer, which might be determined by comparing check plots with treatment plots using regression models.   


### 3.2 Research questions or hypotheses (optional)
If appropriate, list 1‚Äì3 questions/hypotheses.

-  To determine the sufficient source, either triple superphosphate (TSP) or monoammonium phosphate (MAP), and the rate of P required to achieve 95% relative yield in corn and soybean in southern Ontario.
